post_text: Today is Patriot Day 9-11-2020. It's when we remember the events and lives lost on September 11, 2001, and all of the brave rescue workers (fire, police, EMT, etc.) who risked their lives to save others. And then the brave men and women who serve our country in the military and work day in and day out to protect our freedoms and keep us safe from any other tragic event, like this one, from ever happening on US soil again. Our students may not have been able to gather and commemorate this day as they have done in the past, but we want to be sure and thank all of these individuals for keeping us safe each and every day. We will NEVER forget...not even during a worldwide pandemic! わ

post_text: As you may know, the new 14-day Wright County COVID-19 case rate numbers came out this morning and the number is up to 20.11. While we know that puts us in the parameters of 20-29All schools in Hybrid Learning, this does NOT mean that we will automatically move into that model. The decision to move into another learning model will be based on the guidance we receive from the Minnesota Department of Health, our Regional Support Team and Wright County Public Health. Once we have received guidance from those entities, we will notify staff and parents if there is a need to change the learning model for our schools. We will continue with In-Person Learning for all elementary schools and Hybrid Learning for the middle and high school until we receive further guidance. Stay tuned...(and remember to be kind).

Mental Health Monday
Central Minnesota Mental Health Services (CMMHS) has partnered with BHM Schools to provide outpatient mental health services for students for a number of years. This is a very fluid situation that we are working through as best we can with the information that is coming to us from the governor, the Minnesota Department of Health and the Minnesota Department of Education. Rumors fly around freely in situations such as these and we ask that you listen to and read these rumors with great caution. We thank you for sticking with us and more communications will be shared in the days and weeks ahead.

post_text: THANK a Coach/Advisor Week is Jan 27-Feb 2 in Minnesota. We are so thankful for the individuals who step-up to coach a team or advise an organization or club. We know when students are involved in extra curricular activities it often boosts their academic performance and unlocks any other hidden potential. Coaches and advisors are teaching students how to be leaders, set goals, work as a part of a team and many other important life-long skills. In BCMS we have about 65 coaches/advisors and 125 at BHS. Some may work in the district, but many are also community members who make the commitment to our students. This week, be sure to say THANK YOU to your child's coach/advisor and let them know how much you appreciate their extra work and effort to make your child the best person he/she can be.

post_text: Do you have a child who will be 5 by September 1, 2020 and enter kindergarten in the fall? BHM Schools has a variety of choices for parents. Discovery Elementary is one of them. Discovery bases their enrollment on a lottery (drawing) process. Kindergarten is in a stand alone class, but then grades 1-2 and grades 3-5 are grouped together and the students are with the same teacher for those grade levels (this is called multi-age/looping). Discover what Discovery Elementary is all about TONIGHT, Tuesday, January 28 at 6:30pm in Discovery's Commons A.

post_text: THANK YOU BHM ESPs! Minnesota Governor Tim Walz has proclaimed January 27-31 as Paraprofessional Recognition Week. Our ESPs (Educational Support Professionals or Paraprofessionals) help students in the classrooms with reading, math and more. They can also be found on the playground, in the lunch room, health offices, media centers and at the bus stop. They are a valuable people in our educational system and in the daily lives of our students. So if you know the ESPs in your school or perhaps one works directly with your child, be sure to give them an extra THANK YOU for all of the work they do to ensure our students have an environment where they can DREAM, BELIEVE and ACHIEVE!

Understanding Gifted Learners:
Supporting Parents on the Journey

Thursday, January 30 - 6:30 pm
Discovery Center Board Room
Speaker: Teresa Boatman, Ph.D.

As parents, understanding gifted children is sometimes a puzzling journey. This evening explores how intensities, executive functioning, and the unique profiles of a gifted learner can impact overall success. Join us in discussing these complex, but very fun, children and adolescents.

Teresa Boatman, Ph.D. specializes in assessment and interventions with gifted children and adults. She is a clinical psychologist with a private practice in Plymouth, MN. Teresa is also president of the Minnesota Council for the Gifted and Talented and has raised two gifted children.

Reservations are not required, however if you know you will be attending please use this link below to indicate the number attending for planning purposes.

Requests to assess for the BHM School District's Quest program are due this Thursday, January 23, 2020. The Quest program services highly gifted students (top two to three percent in class) in grades 2-9 and is a tuition-free school within a school located at Parkside Elementary (grades 2-5), Buffalo Community Middle School (grades 6-8), and at Buffalo High School (grade 9). The tuition free program is a school-within-a-school for highly gifted students who will be in grades 2-9.

The program combines enrichment and acceleration of district curriculum servicing students in grades 2-9. Students can expect to learn at a faster pace than in a regular classroom and apply what is being learning to the world and connections to the community.

For more information or to see if this program might fit your child, check out www.bhmschools.org/quest-program.

Martin Luther King Jr. was one of the greatest civil rights leaders of all time. He had a dream and we commemorate his legacy on this day. BHM Schools strives to provide an environment where students can "Dream, Believe and Achieve." What's your dream?

This photo is from Washington DC, August 24, 2013. Messages were posted on a board in remembrance of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. for the 50th anniversary of the civll rights march on Washington DC. The original civil rights march took place on August 28, 1963. These messages are at the King Center Imaging Project at a park near the Martin Luther King, Jr. Memorial in Washington DC.
